{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3678258,"name":"Omri Halevi","username":"Omrih664","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/omrih664/{size}/167298_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-10T16:39:30.264Z","cooked":"

We’re excited to be one of the 50 teams selected to alpha test the new System Core. A few days ago, we received our unit, and after seeing other teams start blog threads to share their testing, we decided to do the same.

06 July – First Steps (Mostly Electrical)

The first time we played around with the System Core, it was mostly on the electrical side. We got some of the Molex connectors and wanted to see how crimping them feels. Since we already crimp almost all of our cables, it made sense to give it a try.

We used the same crimp tool we use for PWM connectors, and it worked fine.

Some quick notes about the connectors:

  • The Molex connectors are keyed, so you have to pay attention to the order you insert the wires.
  • They don’t release as easily as the PWM ones we’re used to.
  • They’re more expensive than the PWM ones.
  • The old PWM connectors work in the Molex ports.

We also made a simple adapter plate so we could mount the System Core using the same holes as the roboRIO.

we added labels to all the ports and LEDs.

After wiring everything up, we powered it on for the first time, mostly just to see the screen and LEDs light up.

IMG_99291920×2560 161 KB

13 July – First updates

Today we hit our first issue when trying to update the System Core from one of our computers. For some reason, it didn’t work on that machine. Luckily, we managed to update it to Alpha 4 through another computer.

After the update, we connected a Falcon motor. We tested it first on CAN bus 0 everything we tried worked fine. Then we tried moving it to other CAN buss also was fine.
Next, we wanted to try using a REV magnetic limit switch as a digital input. That didn’t seem to work. We’re going to start a conversation about the Smart I/O ports to understand what’s expected of them in this stage.

After failing with the REV limit switch, we just used stripped wires instead, that worked! so we got musical
video

Finally, we tried connecting LED Strip, but we didn’t manage to get that working. The robot code keeps crashing when we try.

IMG_00921920×1440 314 KB

Omrih664:

Next, we wanted to try using a REV magnetic limit switch as a digital input. That didn’t seem to work. We’re going to start a conversation about the Smart I/O ports to understand what’s expected of them in this stage.

This should be working, although I wonder if its expecting a pull up rather then a pull down. Something to test. How did you have it wired?

Omrih664:

Finally, we tried connecting LED Strip, but we didn’t manage to get that working. The robot code keeps crashing when we try.

Expected behavior, that hasn’t been merged yet into WPILib.

Thad_House:

This should be working, although I wonder if its expecting a pull up rather then a pull down. Something to test. How did you have it wired?

Same as we would to connect the RoboRio. I did not take a picture of the wiring.
The LED on it did light up, but no signal.

14 July – System Core WiFi is Nice

Today our students took the System Core to our practice field, and they were able to connect to it from the far side of the field using its built-in WiFi. They are excited to work with no radio.
video

About the Sensor Issue
After looking at the problem from yesterday again, looks like we need to use a 4.7 kilo-ohm pull-down resistor. Right now, the only one we have on hand is 120 ohm, so we’ll acquire the correct one and give that a try.

We also tried working with the beam break sensor we like. Same story as the REV magnetic limit switch.

On the other hand, we tested the Time-of-Flight LiDAR distance sensor that we like, and it seems to work fine with the System Core.

About the Update Issue
We also looked into the update issue from yesterday, tried again, and shared it in the Git.

Great work! Happy to see WiFi is working so well (which also offers somewhat of a solution to the 2.4GHz radio).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-14T20:31:52.954Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":431,"readers_count":430,"score":166.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504132,"topic_slug":"3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog","display_username":"Yishai Levy","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":37228,"username":"Omrih664","name":"Omri Halevi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/omrih664/{size}/167298_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57809,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator"},"post_url":"/t/3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog/504132/6","custom_user_title":"Team Captain, Programming Lead & Operator","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"hugs","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681443,"name":"Ryan Reed","username":"Ryan_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ryan_reed/{size}/268514_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-15T01:00:56.723Z","cooked":"

I could be totally wrong here but I’m not sure adding a pull-down resistor is going to help. Looks to me like the pull-down inside the systemcore is pulling the DIO down (as seen by the DIO changing state when being shorted to high with the bare wires), so it’s always reading low, even before the Hall effects are triggered by the magnet. You can confirm by measuring the voltage on the sense pin without the limit switch being triggered.

The roborio has pull-up (rather than pull-down) resistors on the DIO, so that was not a problem.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-15T01:00:56.723Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":432,"readers_count":431,"score":116.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504132,"topic_slug":"3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog","display_username":"Ryan Reed","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":37228,"username":"Omrih664","name":"Omri Halevi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/omrih664/{size}/167298_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66264,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog/504132/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681460,"name":"Eugene Fang","username":"Eugene_Fang","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eugene_fang/{size}/65109_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-15T01:45:27.071Z","cooked":"
Ryan_Reed:

The roborio has pull-up (rather than pull-down) resistors on the DIO, so that was not a problem.

We noticed this when looking at the specs as well. Unfortunately, due to the low value of the internal pull-down resistor, it’s difficult to turn this into a pull-up with a passive circuit. I started a discussion about it here and it seems like future revisions may have a higher resistor value.

Omrih664:

We also tried working with the beam break sensor we like.

For putting SystemCore on our 2025 robot, we plan on making a simple inverter circuit so we can continue to use our existing beam break sensor.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-15T02:37:33.826Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":423,"readers_count":422,"score":179.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504132,"topic_slug":"3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog","display_username":"Eugene Fang","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":"The-Blue-Alliance","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/0/2/02b18ea7720fea44e77469bb5261acf1c7045a6e.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":67,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/wpilibsuite/SystemCoreTesting/discussions/120","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"IO pull-up vs pull-down · wpilibsuite/SystemCoreTesting · Discussion #120 · GitHub","clicks":28}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance"},"post_url":"/t/3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog/504132/8","custom_user_title":"604 Alum & Mentor | The Blue Alliance","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3681668,"name":"Omri Halevi","username":"Omrih664","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/omrih664/{size}/167298_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-15T13:10:52.706Z","cooked":"
levyishai:

Looks like the video is private.

fixed

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-15T13:10:52.706Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":387,"readers_count":386,"score":137.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504132,"topic_slug":"3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog","display_username":"Omri Halevi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37228,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3075 - Mentor/Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog/504132/9","custom_user_title":"3075 - Mentor/Alumni","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3682064,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-16T04:19:37.714Z","cooked":"

DIO inputs with pull-down resistors is an unusual choice. All the sensors I have encountered in FRC have been the type to work with pull-up resistors.

In the equipment I have designed or worked on for industrial applications, some have configurable to give the user the choice of pull-up or pull-down resistors. When they only give one option, it is always pull-up resistors.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-16T04:19:37.714Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":376,"readers_count":375,"score":125.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504132,"topic_slug":"3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog","display_username":"philso","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15467,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog/504132/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3685335,"name":"Omri Halevi","username":"Omrih664","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/omrih664/{size}/167298_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-20T14:55:54.684Z","cooked":"

20 July – Pneumatics and Co.

In the past few days, I was overwhelmed by work and wasn’t able to update here, so this is a recap of all of that.

We connected the REV Pneumatic Hub and a full pneumatic system, and operated it with no issues at all.

We also added a SPARK MAX also worked fine, no issues.

We checked AdvantageScope, which looked good as well.

We tested and played with using the Xbox controller, didn’t see any issues there either.

The only issue we observed is the screen sometimes blanking. The students will try to explain and describe the issue better and upload it to the Git if it happens again.

We plan on connecting it to our 2023 robot in the coming days!

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-07-20T14:55:54.684Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":358,"readers_count":357,"score":176.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504132,"topic_slug":"3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog","display_username":"Omri Halevi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37228,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3075 - Mentor/Alumni"},"post_url":"/t/3075-systemcore-alpha-test-blog/504132/11","custom_user_title":"3075 - Mentor/Alumni","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3685457,"name":"Mert Ata BABER","username":"BABER","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/baber/{size}/173331_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-20T15:38:41.801Z","cooked":"
Omrih664:

The only issue we observed is the screen sometimes blanking.

By blank, do you mean the screen turns off and doesn’t display any text? If so, that behavior is intentional and was introduced in Alpha 2 or 3. The screen turns back on when the IMU detects movement.

Omrih664:

We got some of the Molex connectors and wanted to see how crimping them feels

Hey there!
What exact molex connector did you use? I ask regarding both the crimping contacs + connectors.
Is the standard Molex SL 70021 compatible with the system core? (i.e. the locking PWM connectors recommended by andymark)

GitHub

Molex SL Connectors · wpilibsuite SystemCoreTesting · Discussion #11

With SystemCore using MolexSL everywhere, here's some links to all the crimps and connectors. For plugging into SystemCore: Female Terminal https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/molex/00160201...

List of connectors are avaliable here.

Yes. According to the SystemCore specifications the connectors are Molex SL 171971-0003. The color coding appears to be correct for that Andymark cable with the SystemCore as well. 70021 appears to be the male contacts, you’ll want Molex SL 70058 with SL 70066.

I can’t find a video, but the kids will try to catch that and add it to the Git.

It is expected for the SC screen to turn off when no movement is detected. Tapping the screen will cause the IMU to detect some movement and turn the screen back on. We also turn the screen on by tapping the SC. I’m not sure if what you’re experiencing is something different from this.

This is the exact behavior we experience with it as well. Any slight movement causes it to turn back on. I dropped a hammer about 3ft away from the robot on a concrete floor and the vibration from that was enough to turn it back on, it’s super sensitive.
